10.92.text:
Don: Holly's actually a 
very adaptable dog.

15.30.text:
She seems to know exactly
what's inside my head.

19.17.text:
I don't know how
she does it.

23.60.text:
Having a guide dog has 
meant so much to me.

28.01.text: He's how I get to work.

29.48.text: And he's how I get home.

32.75.text:
He's like my baby and
my companion.

35.34.text:
He enriches my life
by just being in it.

39.94.text:
Humans have a close
affinity with dogs...

42.09.text:
because we've lived in close
proximity for thousands of years.

46.30.text:
Guide dogs have a very
intense role with their owners.

50.01.text:
They are more in tuned with
them than many pet dogs, I think.

68.97.text:
Holly is a very happy
and joyous dog...

73.04.text:
who loves it when
the door bell rings.

86.48.text:
She has a birthday
in December...

94.03.text:
I don't know which of
us who will last the longest.

96.34.text:
We will have to wait
and see.

105.18.text:
I had some sight up until
the age of seven.

112.30.text:
which meant that I either
lost my life or lost my sight.

122.93.text:
The Seeing Eye Dog Training 
Unit in Morristown, New Jersey.

127.97.text:
Which is the birth place of
modern guide dog training.

135.44.text:
When I went to Britain as a 20 year 
old to train as a Physiotherapist.

141.10.text:
Before I came back to 
New Zealand I said...

143.24.text:
I must get myself
a guide dog.

149.10.text:
at the Physiotherapy
School For The Blind.

152.74.text:
I was born with 
a sight defect.

156.94.text:
I'm legally blind but I have 
broad peripheral vision.

161.50.text:
So, I feel that I have got a 
good functional level of sight.

168.53.text:
Don is very generous 
with his guide dogs.

171.38.text:
We are allowed to love them 
as much as we want to.

178.96.text:
Don: The first dog
I got was Jassle.

182.49.text:
Jassle was the 4th
guide dog in New Zealand.

185.97.text:
There were three
others before me.

188.27.text:
Of course, guide dogs were 
very unusual in New Zealand.

191.51.text:
Many of us did talks
around the country.

194.52.text:
We had to publicize the 
benefits of guide dogs...

197.78.text:
and the ability to bring 
them into restaurants...

204.77.text:
So, we were a band 
of pioneers really.

211.19.text:
Jassle first came back
to Auckland in the mid-60s.

216.07.text:
I rang up the bus 
company and said...

218.35.text:
I've got a job at 
Auckland Hospital...

220.47.text:
and I'll be catching
the 7.30am bus.

222.45.text:
They said, "Sorry Sir, no you can't 
bring your dog on the bus."

225.35.text:
"It's totally prohibited and
against the law."

231.91.text:
So, the Howick Bus 
Company said...

234.01.text:
"Show us what this
dog can do?"

236.83.text:
"Does this dog really hop on 
the bus and keep quiet?"

240.93.text:
"Yes" I said, and they said, "We'll 
take you for a ride around the block."

245.61.text:
Jassle jumped onto the bus and
went straight under the seat...

248.49.text:
as they are trained to do
and he drove me round the block.

252.13.text:
And Jassle stayed 
nice and calm.

259.34.text:
And, "Not only can you bring your 
dog on the bus at any time,"

264.41.text:
"but I will give you a
free pass as well."

267.55.text:
That was the beginning
of giving me some confidence...

270.27.text:
that guide dogs could begin to
be accepted in New Zealand.

277.51.text:
We managed to get the 
Dog Registration Act changed...

280.61.text:
so that guide dogs could
go into public places.

284.71.text:
And happily that's the
way it now stands.

300.67.text:
here at Guide Dog 
Services every year...

303.53.text:
because we need variety.
They need to be perfect.

307.52.text:
They need to have perfect health, 
they can't be scared of things.

311.06.text:
They need to pass about 55 tests 
that we put them through.

321.92.text:
Donna is what we call
a maiden bitch.

324.11.text: This is her very first litter.

327.99.text:
And they will be six 
weeks old tomorrow.

331.07.text:
We bring them up 
to this room...

333.31.text:
and we have all this colorful stuff 
for them to explore and play with.

338.49.text:
New experiences, that's what the
little mirror is about, on the wall.

341.49.text:
So they can start to see themselves
and go, "What's that?"

344.01.text:
"Am I happy with that?
Am I not?"

347.11.text:
All the lovely colorful dangly things
you can see from the ceiling...

350.21.text:
are there deliberately to try and
help teach them to look up.

354.56.text:
In the wild, dogs don't have any
predators that attack them from above.

359.15.text:
So, looking up is not
natural for them.

360.73.text:
But we need them too if they're 
going to be guide dogs.

362.95.text:
So that guide dog handlers don't get 
a tree branch in the shoulder or head.

374.37.text:
and they're able to
learn a huge amount.

378.53.text:
Guide dogs are very
adaptable and they need to be...

381.71.text:
because they're exposed
to a lot of different events.

385.26.text:
And they have to go
to different destinations.

389.74.text:
We have guide dog handlers who
work in the middle of Auckland city...

393.30.text:
trains, planes and buses, all over
New Zealand for business purposes.

397.15.text:
They need a dog like 
Head Dot there.

400.17.text:
He's the most confident puppy
that we've had in a long time.

407.80.text:
We have other slightly
older people, retired...

411.21.text:
and they like to take it slow up to 
the local club 2-3 times a week...

414.36.text:
or to the dairy or go 
and visit friends.

416.85.text:
So, a quieter type of
dog is needed.

424.20.text:
We're encouraging them
to try new things.

425.71.text:
Encouraging them to climb
on those colorful objects.

429.14.text: And we let them fall off.

432.85.text:
If everything as much as 
possible is positive...

436.20.text:
and we let them develop
at their own speed,

438.72.text:
then they'll get more
and more confident.

441.02.text:
And that is one of the
key things we need -

461.88.text:
the puppies are placed with a 
puppy walker at 9 weeks of age.

465.90.text:
And they have them from
a year to 16 months.

472.50.text:
The role of the puppy walker
is hugely important...

475.16.text:
because we need to get
them bonding with that dog,

478.13.text:
and also developing the
idiosyncrases and individuality...

482.42.text:
that each puppy can
have to offer.

490.24.text:
I was dropping him
off at school...

493.38.text:
and saw somebody with
two Labradors.

495.87.text:
I said to them, "My son wants 
a dog but I'm not too sure."

499.50.text:
She said, "Have you thought
about puppy walking?"

503.96.text:
I had never heard
of it before.

505.52.text:
So, I went home and Googled 
it and was very interested.

511.90.text:
The role of the puppy walker
is to socialize her to different areas.

517.73.text:
So anything that has different
sounds, noises, smells, people.

526.49.text:
Training experience is
the rubbish truck...

528.72.text:
because the noise can
really unsettle them.

534.96.text:
But what we tend to do
is just watch them.

539.02.text:
Not make a big 
deal out of it.

541.00.text:
And if their body 
language changes...

550.18.text:
or feed into that fear
or uncertainty.

553.98.text:
Just say in an upbeat way,
"You're okay, you're alright, let's go."

561.71.text: I am very connected with her.

564.66.text:
They are with you
more than pets...

568.26.text:
because you do grocery
shopping with them...

571.00.text:
you go to the pool with
them with your kids...

573.18.text:
or you go to sports and
restaurants with them.

575.35.text:
She's been on date night
with my husband and I into the city.

593.75.text:
As a puppy walker you always
want your puppy to do the best.

598.13.text:
You never want to think that
you're the person that's failed them.

603.91.text:
This is a bit like having a 
Plunket checkup, I love it.

609.83.text:
So, Leila has just come
out of kennels?

613.98.text:
Nicky: She struggles a bit 
with her adaptability...

616.80.text:
when she's away from
me, it seems.

619.37.text:
I would suggest that in the home 
over the next few weeks,

623.08.text:
change things that you
do around here.

625.93.text:
If you normally feed her at
7pm, change it to 8pm.

628.48.text: And vary where you sleep her.

631.72.text:
I would be visiting Nicky,
to supervise her puppy Leila,

635.37.text:
to check on the progress
she's making...

637.43.text:
to set new milestones for
her along the way.

640.55.text:
And also to offer support and coaching 
for Nicky as a volunteer walker.

655.25.text:
"Pull her back and stop,"
good that's right.

662.31.text:
Nicky: Leila, Leila,
back and stop.

673.15.text:
You may not feel like
you're winning.

675.36.text:
But you're teaching her that,
"Okay I do have to keep stopping."

683.43.text:
Well done, and heaps
of praise.

689.67.text:
This is a lot they need
to learn and cope with,

692.15.text: so they need to be confident.

694.60.text:
The latest way of training
is all positive reinforcement.

698.93.text: And there is no punishment used.

701.41.text:
What we do if we don't 
want a behavior to occur...

703.29.text:
is do what we call
"Extinguish it" by ignoring it.

709.32.text:
Nicky: I normally have to walk her 
down this section of the footpath...

712.27.text:
because she loves all
that down there.

714.80.text:
That's how we train them,
for a client there are billboards,

718.35.text:
rubbish bins, so we want them
nice and central as they go.

723.06.text:
So just move her back on
this side and shorten the lead.

729.39.text:
Nicky: Leila, sit, sit.
Good girl, settle.

733.95.text:
That was a good opportunity
to see tha dog outside the library...

737.41.text:
It's something I'm uncertain of
at times, so it's nice to get your input.

745.96.text:
Definitely her level of
dog distraction is high and...

748.23.text:
if she was a working dog it wouldn't
be acceptable for her to behave like that.

752.69.text:
But we have to remember that
she's just over 12 months old.

756.98.text:
Nicky: She's trying to get to
the crumbs under the table.

762.39.text:
Nicky: Good girl, settle,
good girl, settle, that's it.

770.04.text:
When our puppies do 
wear their red coats,

772.11.text:
we do deem them 
to be working.

774.08.text:
The majority of puppies 
would spend...

776.15.text:
a couple of walks a day
in their red coat.

778.59.text:
But the rest of the time
it is fun time.

785.34.text:
The play time is equally
important for them.

788.50.text:
They are puppies, they're
not miniature guide dogs.

791.07.text:
So they need to release energy
and have fun at the end of the day.

800.51.text:
Noah, my seven year old
has grown so much with Leila.

809.98.text:
He spends a big part of his day
just lying on the carpet cuddling her.

816.34.text:
And in the mornings before school
they lie on the kitchen floor...

820.01.text:
paw to paw and nose
to nose.

825.27.text:
There's recent research 
come out of Japan

827.68.text:
and they looked at what 
we call 'puppy dog eyes'

830.68.text:
where people stare into 
each others eyes,

833.28.text:
or stare into a puppy's eyes
and they feel a lot of love.

838.32.text:
There's actually a 
release of Oxytocin.

840.55.text:
What they've discover
is with the puppies...

842.88.text:
equivalent to when a mother 
and baby look at each other,

846.42.text:
and there's a bonding 
process that goes on.

853.47.text:
similar to the emotions
that we experience.

856.64.text:
So they will be sad, they maybe 
unhappy about something.

862.91.text:
I don't know sometimes how 
I'm going to pass her back.

867.75.text:
You have to tell yourself that
you are their foster parent,

872.32.text:
that they are not your pet
and it's going to be hard.

876.38.text:
But you are doing it 
for the greater good.

902.18.text:
I get up about 6.30am
sometimes a bit later.

906.84.text:
I have my shower and Prentice
tends to wait outside the door.

916.18.text:
Then I feed him and that's
his favorite part of course.

921.39.text:
He watches Mum eat and
waits patiently, sometimes.

926.00.text:
Usually he just 
wants to get going.

928.14.text:
So, I quickly have my breakfast
and then we're out the door.

931.74.text:
Walking up to the bus station
and ready for work.

934.54.text:
He gets excited going to the
bus station because he loves to work.

950.80.text:
I was born with 
Congenital Cataracts.

953.84.text:
In both eyes I was 
completely blind.

957.72.text:
So they did about 13 surgeries
before the age of four.

961.96.text:
They managed to give me 
some sight in my right eye.

964.62.text:
And pretty much none
in my left eye,

969.16.text:
I can see very large print
up close for a short period.

976.52.text:
Maybe half a meter in front
of my face to see basic things.

994.70.text:
The thing with the 
harness is that...

996.74.text:
it allows you to feel the
body movements of the dog.

998.91.text:
I can feel when Prentice
turns his head left,

1000.87.text:
I can feel when he 
turns it right.

1002.72.text:
I know when his attention will
jerk away to something else.

1006.85.text:
When he's suddenly alert 
his body becomes stiff.

1010.44.text:
His whole aura, for me, becomes
very tense and unsure.

1025.59.text:
You've got to trust that your dog 
knows exactly what they're doing.

1029.42.text:
And if they say, "Stop"
then you stop.

1037.85.text:
The guide dogs will be happy to do 
exactly what their owner tells them.

1042.10.text:
But a guide dog has to
think twice about something

1046.37.text:
when it's told to, "Go forward"
and there's traffic coming.

1049.02.text:
The dog needs to be able to say,
"No it's not safe I'm not going."

1053.51.text:
They certainly can make
snap decisions on their own.

1057.24.text:
I was with my guide dog
instructor once,

1059.15.text:
we were chatting and
walking along the street.

1060.78.text:
And suddenly Prentice stopped
and a car screeched in front of us.

1065.11.text:
He actually saved all
three of us really.

1072.49.text:
It does seem a lot of 
pressure to put them under.

1074.99.text:
And yes it is pressured,
it's a hard job that they do.

1078.61.text:
But they seem to cope
very well with it.

1081.53.text:
And they also have the up
side of constant companionship.

1120.12.text:
He ignores everyone, he's
very "mummy orientated"

1127.95.text:
Almost from day one 
he was watching me.

1130.93.text:
He sort of knew that I was
going to be the person...

1134.03.text:
that he protected
and looked after.

1165.80.text: This is my very first job.

1168.43.text:
I'm really enjoying it.
I love working here.

1170.67.text:
I love the people and
I love the environment.

1173.67.text:
We're in the National offices for
New Zealand Blue Light Adventures.

1176.37.text:
We're a youth charity and
work with kids at risk.

1182.93.text:
It took us a bit to get use to the 
protocols around having a guide dog.

1186.22.text:
You're not sure when you can play 
with the dog and when you can't.

1190.17.text:
And Michelle's helped
us through that.

1193.82.text: It's a complex relationship, I guess.

1195.81.text:
When he's got the harness on,
the way he behaves...

1198.44.text:
and looks after her is
really remarkable.

1200.82.text:
And quite a different dog
with the harness off.

1202.83.text:
And we can play with him like
a normal dog without the harness.

1205.83.text:
Throw the ball for him
and pat him.

1210.34.text:
They switch as soon as
you put the harness on,

1212.96.text:
they change and switch.
And that's really important...

1215.40.text:
because they've got that measure of 
what they should be doing at that time.

1225.64.text:
"Hot cholocate, let's go
find the door."

1231.92.text:
Prentice knows where 
each isle starts.

1234.78.text:
When I say, "Find the next isle"
he'll find the next isle for me.

1238.53.text:
And he will watch out for any
trolleys or other little obstacles.

1243.75.text:
He will weave me
around people.

1245.92.text:
He also knows exactly
where certain things are.

1248.69.text:
He often stops right in
front of the chocolate.

1253.64.text:
"It's the chocolate isn't it?
Yes it's the chocolate!"

1264.30.text:
I have a little machine
called "Ruby."

1270.78.text:
or snapshots of things and then
enlarge them on screen to look at them.

1279.63.text:
He knows where the counters 
and self-service checkouts are.

1283.53.text:
And when I say, "Find the 
one that's free, Prentice"

1286.27.text:
he will go to one 
that's empty.

1316.38.text:
Don: Holly's prone to picking 
up bits of rubbish...

1319.75.text:
on Queen Street from 
time to time.

1322.11.text:
She's not adverse to snatching a tissue 
that had a hamburger wrapped in it.

1330.64.text:
So, those are the sorts of things
that need to be controlled a little...

1336.47.text:
because we've got a job
to do here, Holly, (laughs).

1339.59.text:
And we have no time
for loitering in public places.

1345.24.text:
Whereas one of my 
previous dogs, Senna...

1347.81.text:
she stayed close by and
wouldn't leave my side.

1356.12.text:
and you have to work with 
those personalities in a way

1359.08.text:
to really get to know them
and build on their strengths.

1363.20.text:
And that's all part of
that bonding thing

1367.46.text:
that is so critical to a good
working relationship.

1374.67.text:
Working with Jassle
taught me a lot

1383.04.text:
But the bond was really 
demonstrated at the end of her life.

1388.24.text:
One day, Jassle jumped up
to the train and she winced a bit,

1396.36.text:
I took her to the vet and
he x-rayed her.

1400.24.text:
It was determined she had
actually developed a tumor,

1404.62.text:
a sarcoma on her back thigh
and that her leg had broken.

1412.41.text:
So, she worked for a week on this 
broken leg still guiding me about.

1418.08.text:
Once I knew her leg 
had broken,

1422.50.text:
I would go off to work in the 
morning, leaving Jassle at home

1425.86.text:
and she would creep into
our bedroom and get up on the bed.

1429.57.text:
Now, she never did that, 
only in those last days.

1437.71.text:
But it shows the affection
and the bond that there is.

1460.40.text:
Announcer: Michelle Anne-Marie 
Jackson and her helper, Nelly.

1466.24.text:
I got Nelly when I was 
17 years old.

1470.10.text:
She was my guide dog
until she was 11 years old.

1478.25.text:
It was very hard 
when I lost Nelly.

1483.50.text:
I knew it was coming because 
we got the diagnosis of lung cancer.

1487.21.text:
So we knew that it was a matter 
of months, maybe weeks.

1490.34.text:
And it turned out 
to be two months.

1494.12.text:
I had to make the decision, I took her 
to the vets and had her put down.

1517.35.text:
and they're special to our 
whole guide dog family.

1527.79.text:
When one of our dogs
passes away...

1530.00.text:
we organize a plaque and often 
we'll have a memorial ceremony.

1539.62.text:
It's imporant, they are important and
they've done an amazing job.

1561.29.text:
Everybody who's had a dog that's close 
to them and they have lost that dog,

1566.22.text:
they find that they can't just go out
and get another dog to replace it.

1570.48.text: They need that time to grieve...

1572.29.text:
and to remember everything 
they did with the dog.

1575.33.text:
Then they'll come to a point
where they start to long for a dog

1578.70.text: and long for that companionship again.

1582.47.text:
My parents said that they wanted
me to have another dog...

1585.35.text:
because they felt safer with
me with a dog

1588.99.text:
and they knew I was more
mobile and more independent

1593.01.text:
when I had a dog, compared
to having a cane.

1596.97.text:
Years and years later
when Senna was very new,

1601.81.text:
and Jenny came to
visit Senna,

1604.16.text:
she said to Don, "Dad what does 
it feel like to be complete?"

1611.55.text:
And we said afterwards, that
was an interesting comment.

1614.67.text:
But we realized that it 
must have been...

1617.73.text:
how as a small child just knowing
that Don and a dog were a unit.

1631.77.text:
Don: All my four dogs have helped 
at various stages of my life.

1640.61.text:
It's all about loving 
them to bits...

1643.71.text:
and making sure that
that bond is there.

1652.39.text:
It's an unconditional relationship
that they give to you.

1656.69.text:
They're not asking to be judged
or judging themselves.

1666.55.text:
Michelle: It's definitely an emotional 
bond for me, anyway.

1674.43.text:
Because I always get
kisses in the morning.

1676.17.text:
I can just feel
their eyes on me.

1678.94.text:
I love him.
He's my buddy.
